bibl.title: Letter from James E. Peabody to John R. and Ida E. Kissinger, March 30, 1927

div1.p: Peabody informs the Kissingers that a fund is being established for their support.

div1.head: Letter from James E. Peabody to John R. and Ida E. Kissinger, March 30, 1927
div1.opener:
Please return
The Morris High School
166TH ST. AND BOSTON ROAD
NEW YORK CITY
March 30, 1927
---------
THE MORRIS SERVICE LEAGUE
JAMES E. PEABODY
CHAIRMAN THE TEACHER'S COMMITTEE
My dear Mr. and Mrs. Kissinger:
div1.p:
I ought to have thanked you for your letter and
telegram of the 16th, but we have been so busy in your
behalf that I could not seem to find time to do it.
You will see by the enclosed the steps we have taken.
Eleven hundred dollars and more of contributions are in
the Central Trust Company here in New York awaiting our
disbursements. You will not be disappointed, we hope,
when we explain how things must be done. When a drive
of this sort is made, every contributor must receive an
acknowledgement from a recognized organization and must
be assured that every cent will be spent by an authorized
agent well known to the public. The American Association
for Medical Progress of which Dr. Gruenberg is Managing
Director is sending the receipts and banking the money.
We have more than enough to make you and Mr. Kissinger
comfortable during the period of any operation you may
have to undergo. We have communicated with the Red
Cross organization in your vicinity and they will help
you in any way you wish, and will settle for all bills
(receiving our check for these expenditures), so you
will not need to worry about finance.

If you have not already made a decision about what
is best for you to do in regard to the diagnoses of the
doctors. I hope you can delay any treatment until we
can communicate with Dr. Kelly. You know he is an expert
along these lines. Perhaps you can hasten his counsel
if you write him at once what each of your Doctors say.
Where is the fibroid tumor located (stomach, ovary, womb)?
Be sure to write him all the details you know. His address
is 1406 Eutaw Place, Baltimore, Maryland Better send
by special delivery.

I am enclosing a letter from Mr. Charles A. Tyler,
Asst General Manager of the Philadelphia Public Ledger.
Wouldn't it be a coincidence, if, as he thinks, you and
he went to school together: Please be sure to let us
know at once where you were born (I am sorry I cannot
find the statement you have already sent me), where you
went to school, how far you went in school, the year,
month, and day of your birth, and as full an account of
your ancestry and the experiences of your boyhood and
youth as you are willing to give. You understand we do
not wish to pry into your private affairs, but the
The Morris High School
166TH ST. AND BOSTON ROAD
NEW YORK CITY
---------
THE MORRIS SERVICE LEAGUE
JAMES E. PEABODY
CHAIRMAN THE TEACHER'S COMMITTEE
March 30, 1927
newspapers and magazines are running your story pretty
widely, and we wish to keep things as straight as possible.
The International News Service, for instance, had in
their first copy a statement like the following. “Mr.
Kissinger's brave little (not quite according to fact
is it!) wife took in washings all these years, etc.”

I hope the arrangements we are trying to make
will be pleasing to you, and that you will not think we
are trying to dictate as to your future. If we can only
be sure that your coming years are years of comfort,
and that no other Kissinger will be neglected by for
twenty-seven years by the country he has served so nobly,
our labor of love will not be in vain. Please
return Mr. Tyler's letter, and write special delivery,
addressing me 93 Carhart Avenue, White Plains, N.Y.
